channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: The sight of a woman on a bicycle was once considered disgusting and polluting. https://t.co/mp72gbm8bE https://t.co/cmC22QAZt4
A light tour of Wikipedia articles relating to "Web3" sure give the impression that it's mainly about money.

@davewiner Doing this or anything like it should be prohibited explicitly in departmental codes of conduct. Related in spirit: I've heard the suggestion that turning off body cameras should be a felony.
"Twitter is, in many ways, a platform of the elite. [It’s] most powerful as a communication tool for already prominent and influential people." https://t.co/fzQpl8PU9R
We know that people with co-morbidities are more readily brought down by C-19, and in retrospect this surely applies to nations too. https://t.co/UmdJ4SDm2M
@liamputt I will do my best not to make a mountain out of an anthill.

A tiny ant died on the screen of my laptop overnight, and when I tried to brush it away it fell and got lodged in the hinge. The Apple Helpline chatbot won't be of any help, I can tell. RIP, little buddy.
The nation's co-morbidities were surely visible by mid-April of 2020. https://t.co/KNmHfBBdGg

A hunch: Remove the barriers to team teaching by faculty from different fields, and the amount of innovation in higher education would triple. And: The more students got to study topics and problems in interdisciplinary settings, the more relevant they'd find their education.
Designing book pages is an enjoyable challenge. https://t.co/rvlimzkjMr
And Hallmark will introduce a line of thank-you cards to send to helpful robots. https://t.co/vLYkHJrNKI

Mike Pence spent a long time ignoring the people struggling with addiction who would die without access to clean needles.
. . . as Governor of Indiana.

Passers-by stopped to marvel seeing women honored this way, named and recognized for their work. A mother with tears patted her young daughter’s back, a pair of white-haired women clutched one another’s hands, saying, “This matters. This matters so much.” https://t.co/JtTUocdJyf
The Limerick of Sir Terwin https://t.co/JfgrZpQE0b
Thanks to Putin, we're seeing a revival of stories from Soviet times, apocryphal and otherwise. https://t.co/WuWEbBAUvx

'[Three forces] collectively bind together successful democracies: social capital (extensive social networks with high levels of trust), strong institutions, and shared stories. Social media has weakened all three." https://t.co/fV3QvIXPpy

Some things make a lot more sense when they are studied with the tools of more than one discipline. For example, below, both sociology and technological history would be useful in thinking further. The future of universities should probably be increasingly interdisciplinary. https://t.co/VQiunihsKQ

Well, cool . . . the Semantle puzzle imagines each word is something like a club sandwich, or better yet, a Dagwood. I think Bakhtin would have dug it, as he believed that each word carried traces of all its past uses and associations along in its carpet bag. https://t.co/Fodrf7GXcz
Well, that’s my first impression, anyway.
Two kinds of literary translation. One invites in the alien, the other revises it away. https://t.co/XctbfqzKlW

The South Bend (Indiana) Tribune built a new building for a new press in 1994 and sold that press for scrap, I hear, a few years ago. The paper's printing now goes on in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, I believe.
Elements of semaphore. (Don't look at the communication tool alone--look at the social structure elaborated around it, if any.) https://t.co/TLLjDbMqKP
"They have hijacked the word Christian. Jesus is of no use to them." https://t.co/1Lkffs5bpo
The Semantle puzzle links to its source code in the FAQ. https://t.co/TdOfrs8iJg
A fuller set of questions about this: What does it take for our society's "sources go direct" tools to work well? https://t.co/t5y1GWektU https://t.co/LKO6A5OI4S
What does it take for "Sources go direct" to work well? https://t.co/55IQn7NuRw
